div4.p: An act to declare the powers of Boards of Exemption, and to impose penalties on members of such Boards for usurping powers not conferred on them; and to amend the 6th section of an act passed February 18th, 1862, entitled "An Act amending and re-enacting the 2d section of chapter 23, of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mode of exemption," Passed March 11, 1862.

Be it enacted, by the General Assembly, That the true meaning of the act passed February 18, 1862, entitled an act amending and re-enacting the 2d section of chapter 22d of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mode of exemptions so far as the powers conferred upon Boards of Exemption are concerned, is that said Boards of Exemption shall have jurisdiction of the causes of exemption specially act forth in said act, and of no others, and shall pass on no case of exemption until the person claiming exemption has been drafted for actual service.

That, in every case where a discharge is granted by a board of exemptions, the cause of exemption shall be entered of record, and the vote shall be recorded by yeas and nays.
And if any such board shall usurp powers not conferred by said act, and shall grant a discharge from military service to any drafted person for a cause of which such board has not jurisdictions specially conferred by said act., such discharge shall be void, and each member of such board voting for such discharge and exemption, or who shall fail to perform any duty hereby imposed, shall, for every such offence, be guilty of a misdemeanor cognizable only in the Circuit Court of the county or city wherein such members reside, and shall be punishable by a fine not less than one hundred, nor more than one thousand dollars, and by imprisonment at the discretion of the courts, in the county jail, for a period of not less than one month, nor more than twelve months.
In all cases where substitutes have been actually places in service, and certificates obtained, the board shall decide on the validity of the same.

The 6th section of an act passed 18th of February, 1862, entitled "an act amending and re enacting the 2d section of chapter 22d of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mode of exemption," be amended and re-enacted so as to read as follows: "Every claim for exemption, or excuse, shall be filed with the clerk of the board, who shall issue process for such witnesses as the claimant or enrolling officer may require, and within five days after the draft is made, and on a day to be designated by the board the trial of cases of exemption and excuse shall commence; and the same shall be disposed of in a summary manner as speedily as may be. The clerk of the board shall promptly report to the Adjutant General the name of each person exempted or excused by the board, and the cause of such exemption in each case."
This act shall be in force from its passage.

div3.p: General Orders, No. 11.--
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
Proclamation.
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in cities threatened with invasion--

list.item:
I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial law is hereby extended over the city of Petersburg and the adjoining and surrounding country to the distance of ten miler, and do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that of the Mayor of the city, and that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualifications of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus within the said city and surrounding country to the distance aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal, on the eighth day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
(Signed,) Jefferson Davis.

II. William Pannill is appointed Provost Marshal, and is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation, and will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders: "All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed."

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.

div3.head: Light Artillery Company.
div3.p: --We invite attention to our scheme for raising a Light Artillery company, for three years or the war, to consist of six guns and 150 men. Already upward is of fifty-five good and reliable members are enrolled, and we hope to complete our organization in a few days.
Uniforms of the best quality furnished, and the men put in the field free of expense.
Bounty of $50 paid when the men are mustered in.
Traveling expenses of recruits from other cities, or the country, to this city, will be paid by us.

This company is raised by authority from the Secretary of War, who has promised to furnish us the guns as soon as the company is ready, and we think presents a fine opportunity to those who wish to enter the artillery service and relieve themselves of draft.

Recruit who have already joined, as well as those hereafter connecting themselves with the company, will report at the rendezvous, on the Basin Bank, next door to Crenshaw "Co.'s, on Wednesday, 12th inst., for the purpose of mustering in on Thursday, 13th inst.

div3.p: Having received authority from the secretary of War to raise an independent battalion of Light Infantry, to be used exclusively as skirmishers and scouts, and to be attached to no other corps, except at the discretion of the Commander-in-Chief of the department in which we may be stationed, in times of great emergency, I call for volunteers from my own and other States--men now in service, or who have not yet enlisted — to come forward at this critical juncture, when the primal glory of our arms is partially eclipsed in a temporary gloom, and enroll their names in a corps which will come frequently in contact with the polluters of our soil and the desolator of our homes.

I propose to facilitate the organization of the battalion by offering Captaincies to those enlisting not less than thirty men, 1st Lieutenancies to those enlisting twenty-five, 2nd do. to those enlisting twenty.
Seventy privates will be the minimum for a company.
The usual bounty will, of course, be paid, and subsistence and transportation furnished.
For particulars, address me at Yorktown, or W. H. Scott, Druggist, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p:
--The organization of our company is now nearly completed.
We have the guns secured and all equipments ready as soon as we are mustered into service.
Those who do not immediately volunteer will be obliged to go into the militia service.
The system of substitution has been abandoned by the Government, so that all who are bound for service must now represent themselves in person.
This we announce upon authority.
We then earnestly invoke those who are willing to share with us the fortunes of this war, who would rather appear voluntarily upon the field in defence of their country than be the reluctant soldiers of coercion, to come forward now, this day, and enlist their names as volunteers in a great and glorious cause.
Apply at our office in the Whig Building.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: --The Governor's Proclamation of this date renders it necessary that the members of this command assemble at the rendezvous, in the city of Richmond, without delay.

This is, therefore, to require each and every man enlisted in this company to report for duty immediately.
On arriving in the city report at the store of Darracott, Harris & Co., No. 112 Main st. All the members must appear by Saturday, 16th inst., at the latest.
It is advised that each man bring with him at least one thick, warm blanket, and an adequate supply of suitable under-clothing.
Prompt attention to this order is enjoined on all.
div3.closer:
N. A. Sturdivant,
T. M. Hewitt,
Wm. H. Weisiger,
Chas. R. Darracott.
Richmond, Va., March 10, '62. mh 11--5t*

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--The Infantry Company organized at the office of Dr. Parker, in the Law Building, having received assurance of a "Battery of Light Artillery," it was unanimously resolved, at a meeting held last Saturday night, to adopt that arm of the service.
The guns will be ready unless thirty days. So soon as the company is fully organized it will go into the Camp of Instruction at the Fair Grounds.
All those disposed to join will report as early as possible, at Dr. Parker's office, as the company expects to be mustered in this week.
Meetings held regularly on Wednesday and Saturday nights.

div3.head: Light Artillery Battalion.
div3.p:
--On account of recent enactments by the Legislature, I have had to give up two of the companies I accepted for my Battalion.
I now wish two more companies--one from Virginia, the other from without the State.
Capt. S. T. Martin and Lieuts. Holliday and Garnett are recruiting a company for this command in this city.
Their office is Bank st., 2d door above 12th.

No companies need offer that will not be able to report within a short time.
The guns, I have been assured I shall receive in a short time.

div3.head:
Rally!
rally!! rally!!!
div3.p: --Recruits wanted for the oldest Regiment of Volunteers in the C. S. Army!--Company B, of the 1st Virginia Regiment, having re-enlisted for the war, a number of recruits are desired to fill up its ranks to the full extent of the law. Fifty recruits will be at once received on application to the undersigned.--Fifty Dollars bounty will be paid immediately on enlisting, and subsistence and transportation will also be furnished.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillerymen.
div3.p: --All who wish to join the Henrico Light Artillery, which is fully equipped and in service on the Peninsula, will call at the Clerk's Office of Henrico Circuit Court, in the basement of the State Court-House, where they can get information in regard to the bounty of $50, &c.

div3.head: Virginia Rangers.
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to join a Cavalry corps, in which the hours off duty may be spent in agreeable companionship, are invited to enlist in this one. Twenty recruits will be received if immediate application be made at No. 39, Powhatan House, or at Camp Mercer, Fredericksburg.
None but men of unexceptionable character and habits need apply.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders.
div3.p: Persons wishing to join the Maryland Cavalry will call at the office, corner Pearl and Main sts.

div3.head:
Headquarters,
Evansport, Va.,
February 20, 1862.
div3.p:
Special order No. 38.--All furloughs granted to members of Col. Richardson's regiment (47th Virginia) are hereby revoked, and they are required to join their respective companies immediately.
Those detailed on recruiting service are exempt from the above order.

I am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished, (this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve months men can re-enlist, with me. $50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, under the American Hotel, Richmond, Va. Address me,

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers.
div3.p: --It will be seen by the following proclamation that persons who prefer to volunteer rather than be subjected to the discredit of the militia draft, can do so by coming forward now and declaring their willingness to serve their country of their own accord:

div4.head:
Executive Department, Va.,
March 11th, 1862.
div4.p:
The commandants of companies of volunteers, authorized to be raised by the Governor, which are not yet completed are hereby permitted to fill up their commands by volunteers from the militia of the State until the militia are mustered into service.
No substitutes will be allowed.
div4.closer:
By order of the Governor.
S. Bassett French,
Aide-de-camp.

div4.p:
It will thus be seen that the alternative presented now is, whether Virginians will volunteer to defend the Southern cause, or be subjected into service by force.
As will be seen, this choice must be made at once.
Will not the sons of Virginia now come forward and enlist their names.--Apply at our office, in the Whig Building.

div3.head:
Attention!--Boggs's
Battalion flying Artillery.
div3.p:
The undersigned have authority to raise a Company to form a part of this splendid corps, for which the most approved light Rifled Pisces are now turned out. All those watching to join a first rate company, and avoid the militia, will do well to enroll themselves at once, as the ranks are filling rapidity.
We are authorized to give the most positive assurance that no man enlisting in this company remains liable either to the present call of the Governor, or to any other draft upon the militia.
div3.closer:
Apply at Recruiting Office of the Battalion, Bens street, near corner of 12th.
Bounty down--Fifty Dollars.

div3.head:
Headquarters Department of Henrico.
Richmond, Va.,
March 4, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 3.--

list.item: I. By virtue of authority conferred by General Orders, No. 8, Adjutant and Inspector General's Office, March 1st, 1862, Captain A. C. Godwin is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond and the adjoining and surrounding country, for the distance of ten miles.

II.
The Passport Office is continued at its present location, under the charge of the Provost Marshal.

III.
The distillation and distribution of vinous, spirituous, and mall liquors, or other intoxicating beverage, is absolutely prohibited.
This order will be strictly enforced by the Provost Marshal against all persons found distilling, selling, giving away, or in any manner disposing of such beverages.

IV.
All persons, of every degree, except those in the service of the State or Confederate States, having arms in their possession will deliver the same to the Ordnance Department on or before the 5th of March, 1862; other wise they will be seized and taken possession of by the Provost Marshal.
Arms belonging to the State of Virginia will be delivered to Colonel Dimmock, at the State Arsenal, in this city.
The word arms embraces in its meaning swords, bayonets, rifles, double-barrel shot guns, and pistols of such size as may be useful in the field.
Compensation will be made for private arms delivered up or taken for public use, and Government arms, not in the public service, will be receipted for.

div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. Jno. H. Winder,
Commanding, &c.: L. R. Page,
s Ass't. Adj't. General. mh 5--1w

div3.head: Stuart Horse Artillery.
div3.p:
Wanted--one hundred men, for the above splendid Battery of eight pieces — Blakely Guns and Howitsers — to act as Horse Artillery, every cannoneer mounted; with Gen. Stuart's Cavalry Brigade. Army of Potomac.
I am acting under the following orders:

div4.head:
"Headq'rs.
Cavalry Brigade,
Centreville, February 27, 1862.
div4.p:
"Capt. Jno. Esten Cooke, Volunteer Aid to Brig.-Gen. Stuart, is hereby ordered to proceed to Richmond, on recruiting service for the Stuart Horse Artillery.
He will be governed by the rules and regulations for recruiting of the A. and I. General's Dept. C. S. A.
div4.closer:
"By command of Gen Stuart.
"W. E, Towles, A. A. A. Gen'l."

div4.p:
This will be the finest battery in the service.
It will be commanded by an experienced artillerist, a graduate of West Point.
Every cannoneer is mounted, with horse and accoutrements furnished by the Government.
The company, which is nearly made up, will be increased to 150 men, and as soon as the legal number is obtained there will be an election of officers, and the battery will take the field.

The ordinary bounty of $50 paid.
All persons wishing to join this company are requested to address me by letter, at Richmond, or apply at the Recruiting Office, opposite Goddin's Hall, 11th street, to the or to Robert D. Ward, Esq., who is associated with me.

div3.p: Having been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or a Regiment of Heavy Artillery, for three years or the war, I should be glad to confer with Captains who have companies not yet mustered into the service, and also those who desire to raise companies.

Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection, by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence, from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered.
Twelve months men can re-enlist, singly or by companies, for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty.
To those citizens who have not reported themselves, as required, and who will in a few days be drafted, now is the time, and the last, to serve as volunteers.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies, from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office under the St. Charles Hotel, Old Dominion Insurance Company, Main street. City Post- Office, Box 877.
Robert F. Morriss,
Colonel 179th Regiment.
I have the promise of Armstrong field pieces; and should it be realized, this regiment will enter the field as Light Artillery.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Elliott Grays,
Fort Nelson, Norfolk Harbor,
March --, 1862.

div4.p:
This well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis J. Bossleux. 80 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found at either place of rendezvous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of cajolement, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy response, and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All recruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit confidence.

Special notice.--Having enlisted men enough to muster the company into service, this is to notify those who reside in the counties of Henrico, Hanover, Louisa, Orange, Culpeper, and elsewhere away from the city, to report at a day's notice at the rendezvous to be appointed in this city.
Blankets are scarce, and, when found, costly; and each man is advised to bring with him one thick, warm blanket; also, an adequate supply of under clothing.
A further notification will be given in a few days.
div4.closer:
N. A. Sturdivant,
T. M. Hewitt,
Wm. H. Weisiger,
Chas. R. Darracott.

div3.head:
Recruits--
Richmond sharp Shooters.
div3.p:
--Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments, as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of the war, we earnestly appeal to come forward now and join us at office.
Resides the bounty of $50, uniforms board and lodgings will be furnished free.
Application may be made at our Recruiting office, on Main, between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston & Bransford.

Metropolitan Guard.

div3.head: Naval medical Board of examination.
div3.p: --A Board of Naval Surgeons will convene in this city on the 17th inst., by order of the Navy Department, for the examination of candidates for admission in the naval service of the Confederate States as assistant surgeons during the war.
The age of the candidate must not be less than twenty-one nor more than thirty years.

div3.head: Naval medical Examining Board.
div3.p:
The board assembled in Richmond, Va., on the 27th February, will continue its session for a month.
Candidates presenting themselves, are required not to be less than 21 nor over 30 years of age, and must deposit testimonials of good moral character at the office of the Secretary of Navy.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All members of Livingston's Light Dragoons, will report immediately at Camp Lee, or be treated as deserters.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120.
An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

Apply to R. B. Pleasants of Henry S. Jones, No. 7, Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr. Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, or Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.

div3.head:
Light Artillery!!
battery secured!!!
bounty Fifty Dollars!
div3.p:
The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the service of the Provisional Army of Virginia.
for the war. Each man will be entitled to a bounty of $50 upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 11th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.
Those having substitutes will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.

--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, and call upon our fellow- citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We want, if possible, so raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns, and think this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the county of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co. a, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruited maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of recruits from the country to the city will be paid.

div3.head: Attention, young men of Richmond!
div3.p: Having been detailed to recruit for the First Regiment Virginia Volunteers, (now stationed at Centreville,) a bounty of Fifty Dollars, uniform and subsistence, will be given to all able-bodied young men who may enlist in this, the oldest volunteer regiment in the Confederate States.
For further particulars apply at the recruiting station, No. 8, 10th street, between Main and Cary streets.
div3.closer:
W. W. Harrison,
Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer.
P. S.--Two new companies will be received, as there are at present but eight in the regiment. [mh 3--ts] W. W. H.

div3.head:
Attention, citizen soldiers.
Fifty or sixty
able-bodied men, Wanted.
div3.p:
The undersigned having had considerable military experience, and recently attached to the Wise Legion as Captain of Artillery, desires to organize another similar, company for immediate service in the Confederate States service.
Each man will be paid Fifty Dollars bounty money when enlisted, and have his uniform furnished.
Now is the time to rally for the defence of our country against the base Yankee' invaders.
Headquarters on 10th, between Main and Cary streets.

div4.p:
--And Uniforms Furnished.--The undersigned, having been duly authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Heavy Artillery, to man the batteries at Yorktown, want a few more men to complete the company.
For further particulars, apply to Sergeant James McDONALD, 12th st., opposite the Enquirer office.

Those persons who are desirous of enlisting in my company, will also find a Rendezvous on Franklin st., opposite Messrs Dickinson, Hill & Co., where an officer may be found to enroll them.

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
--The subscribers have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be attached to Major F. J. Boegs's Battalion, to which guns of the most approved kind have been already promised.
As no more flying artillery companies will be received, persons wishing to join this arm of the service will do well to enroll their names at once.
Recent events clearly indicate that Virginia will need the strong arms and brave hearts of all her sons in the impending struggle.
The draft will, within a few days, compel those to take the field who fall to respond to their country's call in this, her hour of peril.
Fifty dollars bounty paid immediately on being mustered in.
Apply at Bayley & White's office, opposite the Law Building.
